sols_html:
The limit definition of the derivative at a point x=a is:

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(a+h) - f(a)}{h}\end{aligned}\]

We notice that the term cos(\(\pi\)/3 + h) in the statement of the question resembles the f(x+h) term in the limit definition of the derivative. If this is the case, f(x) = cos(x) and a = \(\pi\)/3.

We now test these guesses using the limit definition of the derivative. If f(x) = cos(x) and a = \(\pi\)/3, then

\[\begin{aligned} f'\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\cos(\frac{\pi}{3} + h) - \cos(\frac{\pi}{3})}{h}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{\cos(\frac{\pi}{3} + h) -\frac{1}{2}}{h}\end{aligned}\]

If we multiply both sides by 2 we get

\[\begin{aligned} 2f'\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{2\cos(\frac{\pi}{3} + h) -1}{h}\end{aligned}\]

This is the expression we were trying to find, so our guess of the function f(x) and the value a were correct

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = cos(x)\end{aligned}\]

and \(a = \pi/3\).
